sub_title: PhD candidate at Utrecht University | Erasmus Mundus Alumna
summary:
PhD candidate at Utrecht University. 

Attended Ghent University, University of Natural Resources and Life Sciences, and Göttingen University to earn an International Master of Science in Soils and Global Change. 
Graduate from Whittier College with 3 Bachelors Degrees in Environmental Science, Environmental Studies, and Economics.
Interested in soil science, root ecology, and plant physiology.

education.degree_name: International Master of Science in Soils and Global Change (IMSOGLO)

school.name: University of Natural Resources and Life Sciences, Vienna (BOKU)

awards.title: Inducted into the Omicron Delta Epsilon International Honors Society for Economics
Named Vice President of the Honors Society for Economics in recognition of high scholastic achievement in the field
Outstanding Academic Achievement in Environmental Science

projects.title: Carbon accumulation and fractionation in soils beneath hedge rows at early stages after conversion
projects.description: Assessing SOC status and C sequestration potential in cultivated and adjacent hedgerow soils in Lower Austria to investigate the influence of management. This project relies on particle size fractionation methodologies, and analyzes soil characteristics that are known / expected to influence carbon accumulation and fractionation in soil. Such characteristics include specific surface area, and ammonium oxalate extractable Fe and Al. This additional approach allows the exploration of the data from the angle of factors influencing carbon accumulation after conversion of cultivated land to hedgerows.

contributors.headline: PhD candidate at Utrecht University | Erasmus Mundus Alumna

projects.title: Environmental Kuznets Curve Analysis of U.S. State-Level Carbon Dioxide Emissions
projects.description: The paper examines the relationship between state-level carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions and state-level economic growth in respect to the Environmental Kuznets Curve (EKC) hypothesis. The purpose of this study is to assess the existence of the EKC for state-level analysis, and determine what sector within the economy is responsible for the most emissions. Sectors include: commercial, residential, industrial, electric power, and transportation.

contributors.headline: PhD candidate at Utrecht University | Erasmus Mundus Alumna

projects.title: Examining the Possible Existence of an Environmental Kuznets Curve Over Different Time Periods.
projects.description: The Environmental Kuznets Curve (EKC) hypothesis posits that the relationship between economic growth and environmental exhaustion follows an inverted U-shaped curve. This is based on the notion that, during the early stages of development, income per capita and pollution per capita both increase; however, after reaching a certain level of average income, pollution per capita begins to diminish as average income continues to rise due to societal preferences for a cleaner environment. This study tests the EKC hypothesis by examining the relationship between national carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions per capita and Gross Domestic Product (GDP) per capita for 160 countries during the period from 1820 through 2016.

contributors.headline: PhD candidate at Utrecht University | Erasmus Mundus Alumna

projects.title: Role of management and topography on soil organic carbon between grassland and cropland soils in Minnesota: a spectroscopic approach.
projects.description:
• Examined the role of topography on the quantity and quality of soil organic carbon (SOC) between different management practices in Minnesota
• Relied on SOC physical fractionation techniques to detect changes in SOC distribution
• Utilized scientific instruments such as Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR) to qualitatively assess SOC chemical characteristics across management type
• Presented findings at the Undergraduate Research, Scholarship, Creative Activity Conference

contributors.headline: PhD candidate at Utrecht University | Erasmus Mundus Alumna

projects.title: Inputs of Three Different Species into Aquatic and Terrestrial Food Webs
projects.description:
• Looked at herbivory and ecosystem inputs of three different plant species into terrestrial and aquatic food webs at the Mai Po Nature Reserve
• Identified which of the plant species have a superior impact on the different food webs
• Investigated the impact of land use change on the flora and fauna of Mai Po Nature Reserve
• Worked under World Wildlife Fund Hong Kong and proposed management practices that promote conservation within the Mai Po Nature Reserve
• Presented findings at the Undergraduate Research, Scholarship, Creative Activity Conference

contributors.headline: PhD candidate at Utrecht University | Erasmus Mundus Alumna

projects.title: Terrestrial and Aquatic Food Web Inputs of Riparian Plants in Dwarsberg, South Africa
projects.description:
• Studied herbivory and ecosystem inputs of invasive riparian plant species into terrestrial and aquatic food webs at Dwarsberg Trout Hideaway
• Presented findings at the Undergraduate Research, Scholarship, Creative Activity Conference in addition to the Southern California Conferences for Undergraduate Research

contributors.headline: PhD candidate at Utrecht University | Erasmus Mundus Alumna

projects.title: Effects of M. micrantha on Gas Exchange and Light Availability on Mangroves in Mai Po Nature Reserve
projects.description:
• Collected data on the effects of an invasive vine, M. Micrantha, on the mangroves of Mai Po Hong Kong
• Worked under World Wildlife Fund in Hong Kong and suggested practical management strategies for the Mai Po Nature Reserve
• Presented findings at the Southern California Conferences for Undergraduate Research
